text: Growler from the Logan Square brewpub. Dark caramel brownish pour, very nice clarity, big creamy off-white head with exceptional retention. Nose is toffee, roast nuts and toasted pumpernickel. Mouth is medium bodied, toffee, dark bread, cocoa, nuts. Very nice mild. I just finished the growler and could easily drink drink another.
On tap at Revolution. Pours dark brown with a modest beige head and a toffee aroma. There is a sourish caramel malt flavor with a bitter finish.

Pour on tap at the brewery, dark reddish brown pour with thin off white head, aroma brought notes of bread, toast, some red fruits into a bit of cocoa, slight earthy notes with a slight grassy note. Taste was a mix of cocoa, toast, bready notes into a bit of red fruit, hints of earth, finishing slightly bitter. Pretty nice.

My Bottom Line:
Caramel, earthen truffles and toasted cereals move into minerals and leafy hop bitterness in this lean Dark Mild.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam laces around the gleaming ruby brown.
-Fruity angles are also found.
-This is not sweet at all; just lots of clean malt flavors and balancing hops.
-Carbonation could be softer (this one deserves a handpump too!).

On tap at the Milwaukee Avenue location.

A reddish copper ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, sweet nutty caramel malt with grassy hops, light brothy character, nice. In mouth, a nice sweet caramel malt with light nutty notes, grassy hops, light mineral notes, pleasant. On tap at Revolution Milwaukee location.

5oz pour at the Revolution brew pub pours a transparent, caramel amber with some cloudy, white head. Nose has malty notes, toffee, a little loose leaf tea. Flavor has more nutty character to it, toast, still some tea, coffee, brown bread crust. Crisp finish.
On tap @ the brewpub. Old penny copper hue, thin beige head. Caramel and cereal, just a touch if ash, toasty. Comforting. A terrific mild.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: very good mild beer. low alcohol and slight coffee and caramel notes. esay to drink and had a draft pour at revolution brewery in coast. pours brown in color with a tan head.
Black pour from keg at revolution. Light guiness light with a better flavor. Good for what it is
Pours brown with a thin head. Some toasted malt in the aroma. Light flavors toasted malt caramel roast. Light toasted roast. Dry finish. Solid second runnings beer.
Draft; Dark brown color; Light body; Aroma of malt, & some caramel; Flavor of light roasted malt, caramel/toffee, and grain; Decent for a mild ale.

On tap at the brewery. Nothing on the nose that I could tell. Pours a dark brown.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark red pour with a thin wispy head. Aroma is super light and hard to pick up. Light mouth. Aroma is full of grain. Taste is bready. Cereal, biscuit & grains with a slight bitter finish. Very easy to drink. Caramel and some toffee round this out.

milds: most unappreciated style on earth, i love em .. . medium dark brown rust .. . bark and copper wood .. . very light mouth .. . an ok beer, but its very light even for a mild .. . . 

wait!? this isnt faux dive, this is just dive!

On tap at the Kedzie brewery.  What a pleasant surprise for the middle of an afternoon!  Pours a toffee brown with small but lasting beige head.  Aroma is much stronger than I suspected, with toffee, caramel and malts.  Taste is slightly sweet with a trace of hops bitterness in the clean long finish.  Body is light to medium with perfect carbonation.  By far the best and most flavorable low ABV beer Ive tried.  I will make sure to revisit this one on my next trip to the brewery.

Growler shared by Thorpe429 and Amyliz4. Thanks Mike and Amy! This kicked off a nice day of brewing.

A: Toffee brown color with orange highlights and a half inch of light tan head. The head had good retention and left some nice lacing on the glass.

S: The aroma is fairly weak, with some subtle hints of toffee and malt in the English style.

T: The beer is very tasty and flavorful, with enjoyable light roast and a very mild bitterness. The beer is just ever so slightly sweet. This is a really well done brew. Workingman is my first experience with English dark mild ale, so I have no other point(s) of reference, but this seems like a great genre of beer that I will be returning to as soon as possible.

M: Light, thin body, which comes as no surprise with a 3.5% alcohol session beer.

D: Very drinkable. I could throw back several pints of this pretty easily.

Serving type: growler

Reviewed on: 01-04-2011
A nice malty beer. Holds to its description with toffee and caramel. Pretty heavy relative to the low alcohol content. This beer could have supported more alcohol pretty easily.

Draft pours clear rich brown, tight off-white head and great retention.  Aroma is serious toffee, caramel, and malt.  Very mild hop profile.  Taste is incredibly rich given the abv... toffee, caramel, toast, and biscuit.  body is medium/full, rich and mildly frothy, medium carbonation, dry toffee finish. Overall, this was the highlight of my visit to Revolution!  A well made mild is a rare and delicious thing.

Draft at Revolution. Dark nut-brown, thin cream head that stays fluffed, no dissipation, light lacing. Very woody nose, leaf, dry nut, extremely attenuated and soft. Flavor is a little chocolate malt, sugar, considerable leaf and tea, balanced through the creamy finish, lightly bitter in the end, lasting forever. Exceptionally drinkable, enjoyable, and flavorful without any in-your-face.

a fair to midland brew, pours a thin amber brown with a white head that fades quickly. Nose and taste are of sweet toffee malts and muted hops. Not a bad brew, but not something I would run out to the brewery to grab either.

Draft sample. Poured clear reddish brown color with an average fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate complex toffee and malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Soft drinkable beer.

Enjoyed on tap at Revolution Brewery in Chicago, IL while eating dinner with my bandmates.  I enjoyed this towards the end of the meal and practically had to chug it before leaving, so maybe this isnt the most accurate rating, but I remember it being pretty good.  Definitely tasted tame, but not watered down, flavorful but subdued.  Good stuff.

pours a nice light mahogany color

good nose with tones of grains, malts, and bits of toffee. Nose is solid and pretty straight forward

lighter feel that is nice and pleasant with some caramel and toffee with some malts as well

this is a session nice beer. Some good tones but they are lacking some depth

Draft at rev, Finally trying this beer. Sorry I wish more brewpubs offered small beers but I think they should be $3-4, but what do I know. This guy pours ruby red with off white head. Nose has toasted nuts and brown sugar.  Flavors is a bit out of balance on the roasty or better yet toasted side, good amount of bland toasted grain over powers, while some prunes and brown sugar lay underneath. Lots of flavor and good body for a small beer, but the flavor is a bit one dimensional on the toasty side as if its trying to overcompensate for being a small beer. This did grow on me while i drank it but I bet this would play better on cask.

On tap at Revolution.

Pours a fairly-dark brown color with a nice off-white to tan head with moderate retention and a nice cap as it falls. The nose brings forward a good dose of roasted malt. Also there is a bit of coffee and mild chocolate. The flavor is a bit more robust than the nose with all components being a bit more pronounced. Some mild bitterness along with the roast in the finish. Light body and really nice drinkability. Certainly a powerful session beer.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 01-04-2011

The beer pours a clear light brown with a off white/tan head that rises a couple fingers, good retention and lacing.

The aroma bursts with tons of sweetness. There is caramel, toffee, mixed with a little toastiness.

The taste is pretty much spot on with the aroma, lots of sweet toffee notes with a toasted finish. Its a little too sweet for me and its got a slight alcohol taste to me, which is surprising giving the abv.

The biggest problem with this beer is the feel, super light.

Drinkability is ok, a little too sweet for me

Growler courtesy of Dunt on BA. Poured into a DFH tulip glass a dark clear brownish color with the slightest tinge of red. Starts with a 1-2 finger head of tan that quickly settles out to form a collar around the glass. The nose has notes of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate all pretty subtle. Some slight lace left on the glass. Medium/light mouthfeel. A very easy drinking beer with light notes of coffee, caramel, and roast. Not as flavorful as I was holing for but a nice drinker nonetheless.7

Draft at brewpub. Pours clear burgundy hued copper with a foamy white head. Aroma of mild sweetness and caramel. Notes of caramel, toffee, a touch dark fruit. A pleasant and clean bittereness in the finish. A nice ale for the cold months thats not too rich to session.
(Draught)  Pours a deep amber body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of raisins, earth, roasted grain, light cocoa, and herbs.  Flavor of caramel, earth, honey, some cocoa, and florals.

Draft at brewpub. Pours a very dark brown with a light tan head. Roasted malt and bready aroma. Light to medium bodied with a soft and watery texture. Flavor of chocolate malt, nuts, and wet grains. Husky grain finish. For a mild, this is excellent and perfect for when you are done drinking and your brother insists on your getting one more.

Poured from a growler picked up at the brewpub. Lightly clouded, deep brown colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, light brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is pretty nice. Solid mix of toffee, cocoa, caramel, and some roast. A light earth, nut, and some florals. Flavor is similar. You can definitely tell this is lower ABV, but its pretty flavorful for such a light beer. More of an earth throughout with a nice cocoa maltiness. Some more toffee and caramel with a light roasty nut and some floral fruits. Finishes clean and dries evenly with a nice toasty, nutty, cocoa, earth that leaves a light bitterness and a medium length aftertaste. Light, smooth body and soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, for such a low ABV, this is pretty flavorful. Well balanced and very sessionable. I liked this one.

GABF 2010.  Pours a deep dark brown with a light mocha head.  Aroma is dusty nutty chocolate, light roast, hints of earth and grass, mod sweetness.  Flavor is tootsie roll, chocolate, nuts and light earthy flowery honey, dries up and gets more cocoa dust, and cracker with a clean dry mostly smooth finish.  Nice easy drinking.

tap.  pours a clear copper with a small offwhite head. coffee.  toffee.   some light toasty grains.  cereal chacter.  nice dry earthy bitterness.   may have been my favorite beer at revolution of the day.

Draught at the brewpub.   Clear brown with a tight beige head.   Lightly chocolatey and dry, toasted malt aroma.   Definitely has an earthy chocolate malt thing going on in the flavor, with just the lightest hint of sweetness to balance that out.   Lightly fruity but pretty clean overall.   Light bodied and dry enough to quaff en mass.  Pretty simple toasty/malty sweet flavor dynamic.   Not a beer to get in the way of whatever you malt be doing.   I could stand for a little more rich malt character to tame the toasty chocolate, though this might hurt drinkability slightly.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2011 I thought that this was a great mild ale. Very drinkable but there is plenty of flavor. Serving: Tap Had again recently, it is really very nice a session beer with plenty of flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2010 Sample at the brewpub. This beer pours a clear brownish color with a medium tan head that dissipates steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Earthy malt and chocolate in the nose, plus a bit of fruit. Light and smooth body with a nice chocolate malt character along with notes of toasted bread, caramel and hops. The finish is sweet and malty with a lingering roast aftertaste. Above average session ale all around.

Hand pumped pint at Revolution, June 7. Nice Guinness cascade effect. Deep brown in color, deeper than a Newcastle. Toasty malts and hoppy smell. The taste is similarly toasty, but lets in some nice hop character.

On tap at the brewpub.  Pours clear dark brown with a small, lasting tan head.  Aroma is rather roasty with caramel, nuts, and floral hops.  Lots of flavor for the ABV, as the brewpubs description says.  The flavor is roasty with chocolate, caramel, and earthy hops.  Pretty nice palate - a somewhat light body with a dry mouthfeel.  Very drinkable.  A really solid mild ale.

On tap at brewpub. Pours dark hazy brown with tan head. Aromas caramel, toffee, malts, and some faint hops. Flavor is malty with caramel, toffee, and some nuts. Very light hop flavor in there too.  Pretty flavorful mild ale.

Initially did not like this beer, however as my palate got used to it I was able to pick up more of the fruitier notes that balanced the initially cereal and woody flavors. Very clean finish which is good for a beer of this type. Tastes a lot like a light cask ale.

keg-excellent head, great retention.  deep caramel pour, opaque at center.  big lacing.  aroma is subtle caramelized bready notes.  flavor is dark soft pretzels, lightly fruity background.  cask- bitterness is amped out without CO2 to cleanse the palate.  eventually it subsides and pretzels return.  besides obvious head difference (soap scum here), color is far lighter and more translucent as well.

Served a bit too cold at the brewpub. Nice brown color and a great white head of medium fine bubbles that lasts pretty well and leaves a few rings of lace. Nose is mild and porter-ish, lightly roasty w/ some husky grain notes. Quite dry, very on watery but w/ enough roasted malt character to hold it which is, at the very least, acceptable for such a low gravity beer. Some nutty malt character comes out as it warms. finishes mildly bitter and very clean. Satisfying for sure. Id like to see how this develops as Revolutions brewers learn their system.

Draft on tap at Revolution (Chicago, IL). Pours a dsrker copper, some sunfire at the bottom, thicker and darker haze, with a good tannish head that dies to a decent level, laces ok. Aromas are some toasty crisp malts, a touch of soapy florals, mild with faint caramel. Initial is lighter bodied, a touch of soapiness, metal, and grainy malts. Some light toastiness, the caramel, if any, is minimal, as this beer isbready, leaning more towards dry toast with some light floral and grassy hops to give it some life. The hops grow on me, delicate with just faint citrus and a mild bitterness, making this beer quite drinkable. No caramel or sweetness taking me down the path of heavier brews, and at 3.5, this beer could be consumed on the regular. The lacing is minimal, but the beer is fresh, grains and hops taste new, amazing what a fresh mild can do. Toasty grains and mild hopped finish. Nice

On tap at brewery.  Pour is darker than expected; clear copper with a medium tan head; looks full and rich.  Aroma is subtle: caramel malt, light hop, and lightly sweet.  Flavor is also light toffee malt with a faint hop character and lightly sweet.  This is a pretty good beer for being so low in alcohol.  I liked it.

Draft at Revolution. This was probably my favorite of the lot, mostly because Im really into milds right now. Pours a dark and murky brown with offwhite head. Nose is roasty and sweet. On taste, some like grassy notes and a fair amount of carbonation. Has a fair amount of body as well. Pretty solid stuff.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Out of their five beers (so far) this one was the most plain.  Pours brown with a thin tan head.  Light aroma.  Nut and caramel malt in the flavor.  It is a little bit thin, but it is also a 3.5% beer.  Light bitterness as well.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2010 Sample at revbrew... Pours a smooth dark caramel cola brown with a creamy light beige head... Aroma of nutty caramel malt and some citrus hops. Nothing too assertive... Flavors of nuts, caramel malt as well as a touch of citrus hop bitterness in the finish. Soft to medium carb and thin to medium bodied.

On tap.Pours clear, chestnut brown with slight off-white head. Virtually undetectable aroma. Flavor is modestly bitter toasted grains with some toffee and dry nuts. Rather traditional flavor; only way it breaks from the standard mold is in the intensity of the flavor. Thinnish palate. A solid, easy-drinking "mid-day lunch beer" as their commercial description suggests.
